p: Mice gained considerably more weight on the high-fat diets compared to the 5% protein or control diets ( Fig 1A presents the change of weight as a percentage while Supp. Fig 2A–2C presents the weights in grams, p<0.0001 at each time point after week 2). Undernourished mice experienced only slightly lower average weights than lean controls (p<0.05 after eight weeks, except for Balb/c mice. S2C Fig). To further assess nutritional status, we measured serum levels of the adipokine leptin. Leptin, a pro-inflammatory adipokine primarily secreted by adipocytes, is a blood marker that generally increases during obesity and decreases in severe undernourishment [ 45]. Obese mice had significantly increased levels of leptin in their serum following 8–10 weeks of feeding compared to lean controls ( Fig 1B, p<0.0001). Leptin levels in LP mice were not significantly different from controls (p = 0.2935).
